awd_titl_txt: Organic Acids, Bases, Catalysts, and Anion Recognition Reagents
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Steven R. Kass of the Department of Chemistry at the University of Minnesota explores charge-enhanced acids, bases, hydrogen bond catalysts.  The goal of this research is to develop new and useful catalysts, and obtain a better understanding of how these species operate to facilitate their development.   More efficient catalysts are needed in the preparation of chemicals required in our daily life, such as the production of pharmaceuticals and polymers.   This project lies at the interface of organic, physical, and analytical chemistry, and is particularly well suited for educating and training young scientists.  Two patents have resulted from NSF-supported work in this group and a wealth of practical applications ranging from human health and the environment to agriculture and chemical industry may arise from this research.

Charge-enhanced acids, bases, and hydrogen bond catalysts (salts) are being prepared and characterized. Their catalytic abilities are being examined in a variety of organic transformations, and structural variations are being probed to increase their reactivity.  The role of covalent incorporation of the counterion at a remote location in these salt based catalysts are being studied.  Chiral substrates (e.g., thioureas, binols, binol-derived phosphoric acids, and alkaloid bases) are being prepared and their enantioselectivities are being determined.  Catalysts with chiral counterions for double stereodifferentiation are also being investigated.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Inspired by Nature and how enzymes operate, chemists developed organic compounds that exploit hydrogen bonds to facilitate chemical reactions. A new strategy carried out by the Kass group for enhancing this catalytic activity takes advantage of the old adage: opposites attract. That is, there is a powerful attraction between positive and negative charge centers, and so incorporation of the former into a molecule enhances its acidity and catalytic ability. During this recent grant period, the nature of the positively charged center and structural effects were examined to facilitate the development of more useful catalysts. Hydrogen bond donors with the property of handedness (i.e., chirality) were also explored and found to be useful in forming one mirror image compound over the other; a key attribute in modern organic synthesis given that most pharmaceuticals and drugs are chiral. A practical methodology for quantitating the amounts of mirror image molecules was also developed and reported in the primary literature.

The supported research program provided excellent training for young scientists, both undergraduates and graduate students. Large numbers of both groups of students were also exposed to this NSF-sponsored research and the resulting excitement that arises from discovery in introductory and advanced chemistry classes. Domestic and international visiting students learned about this work too over ten week summer periods through the NSF-REU and University of Minnesota Lando research programs that the PI has been running for many years. Numerous societal benefits may arise from this work developing and understanding new metal-free and environmentally friendly organocatalysts.


Last Modified: 10/08/2020
Modified by: Steven R Kass
